stories.text:
I need to figure this out to optimize UX and journey to conversions on my app. In my case, it's about choosing a restaurant. Current apps tend to put first packaging or cuisine type, while food specific taste can be a decisive criteria on the journey to choose a place to eat.

There are a couple studies about the importance of packaging on perceived taste, but none seems to look for a ratio of importance between perceived future taste (packaging, reviews, photos) and known taste (ingredient, dish name, referring to taste memory) when the buy decision has to be made.

About customer journey : Objective past first or subjective future first?
stories.title: What's more important: Taste or packaging (photos/reviews/atmosphere)?

Airbus A340 plane lands on ice runway in Antarctica

stories.text:
I've worked at my current company since my college internship in 2012, and have not sought a new gig in all of that time. The company was a travel tech startup that I joined as an early employee, and it was acquired a few years ago. The app is still active and supported, but it feels time to start exploring what else is out there.

In case it matters, my background is largely in various QA and product roles, most recently transitioning from project management to product management.

Are the traditional places like Linkedin and Indeed the best places to upload resumes, update skills, etc.? Do I need to fully dive into the job-hunting waters and network with recruiters to get a good idea of where I "stack" so to speak?
stories.title: Ask HN: Are Indeed, LinkedIn the go-to places for exploring new jobs?
A Slice of Life in My Virtual Community
